article_title: State, region so far weathering the oil price storm
article_text:
State, region so far weathering the oil price storm Economically diverse state stands up as prices fall, reports net gain in jobs

Photo: Bob Owen /San Antonio Express-News U.S. Army Master Sgt. Fredrick Bishop (left), who will retire next...

October unemployment data indicates Texas will have made it through the 2015 oil bust with a net gain in jobs, Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas Assistant Vice President and Chief Economist Keith Phillips said Friday.

article_metadata.description: October unemployment data indicates Texas will have made it through the 2015 oil bust with a net gain in jobs, Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas Assistant Vice President and Chief Economist Keith Phillips said Friday.  Workforce Solutions Alamo, which reports numbers that aren’t seasonally adjusted for factors such as summer tourism or the start and end of school years, said the region’s employers added a total of 9,200 new jobs.  The education and health services sector added 1,800 jobs and the leisure and hospitality sector added 1,400 jobs, Workforce Solutions Alamo said.  Mining and logging was the only regional industry showing an annual job loss, with 600 local workers getting pink slips over the last 12 months.  [...] retail trade, and leisure and hospitality saw a boost as people spent money saved at the gas pump.  “One striking feature of San Antonio’s real estate market is that there is more activity in single-family home construction than in multifamily,” the economists said in an analysis released Friday.
article_metadata.author.name: By Lynn Brezosky, Staff Writer

og.description: October unemployment data indicates Texas will have made it through the 2015 oil bust with a net gain in jobs, Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas Assistant Vice President and Chief Economist Keith Phillips said Friday.  Workforce Solutions Alamo, which reports numbers that aren’t seasonally adjusted for factors such as summer tourism or the start and end of school years, said the region’s employers added a total of 9,200 new jobs.  The education and health services sector added 1,800 jobs and the leisure and hospitality sector added 1,400 jobs, Workforce Solutions Alamo said.  Mining and logging was the only regional industry showing an annual job loss, with 600 local workers getting pink slips over the last 12 months.  [...] retail trade, and leisure and hospitality saw a boost as people spent money saved at the gas pump.  “One striking feature of San Antonio’s real estate market is that there is more activity in single-family home construction than in multifamily,” the economists said in an analysis released Friday.
